custom_fields.key_topics: The topics of this course will range from practical tools such as source control, IDEs, LaTeX, and UNIX, skills, such as research skills, to general CS information such as emerging CS fields, history of CS, and interesting paradoxes.
custom_fields.prerequisite_knowledge: Prior programming experience is recommended but not required. Interest in any technical field is recommended.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: The final course grade will be calculated using the following categories: Group Presentation; Customized Exam; In-Class Presentation.
custom_fields.goals: By the end of the semester students should be able to Know about the different IDEs and be comfortable with using at least one of them. Know about the different text editors and be comfortable with using at least one of them. Know about the different debugging tools and be able to use some of them. Use LaTeX and understand its importance. Understand what is Git and use Github. Understand the OS debate Linux vs Mac vs Windows and take a position in that debate. Use command line and know how to use to UNIX man. Know about popular CS terms and acronyms. Understand the history of computing and the people that led to the existence of the current computers. Know about the emerging CS fields, and the future of CS. Be up to date with the hottest CS topics.
custom_fields.relevance: This course aims to prepare students to become leaders in both academia and industry, by equipping them with the necessary tools.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Most of the classes are hands-on, so it's recommended that students bring their laptops to class.

long_desc: While the Computer Science curriculum at CMU is very intensive both the theoretical and practical components  many CS students still miss the tools of the trade. This course is intended to introduce the students to many of the tools, knowledge, and skills that they need in order to surviveflourish as computer scientists. The topics of this course will range from practical tools such as source control, IDEs, LaTeX, and UNIX, skills, such as research skills, to general CS information such as emerging CS fields, history of CS, and interesting paradoxes.
name: Student Taught Courses(StuCo): How to Fake Being Tech-Savvy
base_name: Student Taught Courses(StuCo): How to Fake Being Tech-Savvy
